I also can’t figure out whether I am using the ttGlyphPen correctly (can it even record points, or is it just a way to store points to later draw?).


```python
def decomposeGlyph(font, glyphName):

    components = (font['glyf'][glyphName].getComponentNames(font['glyf']))

    ## BASIC IDEA (not yet working)
    # for component in glyph
        # record tt points of component base
        # draw points to glyph
    
    glyphset = font.getGlyphSet()

    for comp in components:
        glyph = glyphset[comp]

items.title: rename-fonts.py does not detect family name correctly
items.body:
Hi,

I am having an issue using rename-fonts.py to add a suffix to fonts exported by Glyphs.

The script attempts to detect the family name by searching the most common name table indices in both Windows and Mac platforms. Failing that, it simply adds the suffix to the end of the font's full name (after Bold Italic, etc.)

However, it seems that the name table it receives from TTFont(input_name) does not contain the full name table - the Mac Roman entries are all missing and for the Windows English entries, only the first six records are present; the rest are also empty.

However, in order to extract just the family name, either Mac Roman #1 (1, 0, 1) or Windows Engl. #16 (3, 1033, 16) name records need to be parsed. Because these are missing, the script always adds the suffix to the very end of the font name, which is not the correct result.

I'm not quite sure why the complete name table isn't being extracted (have tried looking into the code, but to no avail.) Using ttx to output the XML does return the complete name table (as does DTL OTMaster), so the records are there. Therefore, I assume this is a bug.

For the meantime I have written a workaround, which is less stable (uses the hyphen character to try and guess where the family name ends). It would be great to fix this problem at the source. Thanks!

items.title: Default instance is not selectable on macOS Catalina (Fixed in macOS 11)
items.body:
This issue has come up for me and others in several fonts, so I have worked on documenting and testing it today. 

To summarize:
1. Working in a macOS app like TextEdit, try to select the default instance of a variable font.
2. If the font’s default instance is not “Regular,” the style cannot be selected, and the style selection instead goes to something else (usually a Medium weight, for whatever reason).

It seems most likely that this is a macOS bug, so I have filed an Apple Feedback ticket `FB7734904` (leaving this here in case anyone from Apple comes across this).

However, it is also possible that there is something that could be do to the fonts to make this work.

https://github.com/arrowtype/vf-default-instance-test

A simple example: this 2-source font in which Light is the default instance:

![textedit-test_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45946693/84540213-e0995700-acc2-11ea-817a-1b7c3997650c.gif)

This happens on the following fonts, and presumably others:
- Recursive
- Commissioner
- Encode Sans
- Name Sans

Have others experienced this problem? Have you found any solutions / ways to get around it?

items.title: Should we respect explicit subtable breaks?
[ttLib] STAT AxisNameID must be > 255
items.body: This is odd. The [spec](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/typography/opentype/spec/stat#axis-records) says that the AxisNameID must be greater than 255. fonttools currently reuses nameID's wherever possible, but this can lead to an AxisNameID to be less than 256, and OTS warns about that: https://github.com/khaledhosny/ots/issues/210

items.title: Duplicate glyph names: Disambiguated names are invalid
items.body:
The [addition of hash characters](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/issues/1119#issuecomment-347512821) to disambiguate glyph names just bit me again, as the resulting glyph names are invalid.

In my case this is a problem because I'm using an input file in a text format to add information to a font, and there I need to use the glyph names that FontTools is assigning. So I need to use `Delta#1`, but the input file parser treats the `#` as a comment marker, thus breaking my input file.

Could we reconsider to change the logic to produce valid glyph names, as [Just suggested](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/issues/1119#issuecomment-347512821)? Maybe for compilation, we could still support the `#` notation as not to break existing files.

https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/1d6dd50d5246e0ee295eb5d2d363c68973be3a43/Lib/fontTools/ttLib/tables/_p_o_s_t.py#L112-L118

items.title: [feaLib] feaLib parses nonsensical alternate rule without complaining
items.body:
This is a *very* low-priority issue, but... feaLib has provision for prefix and suffix contexts on alternate rules. The OpenType spec doesn't. :-) Given this obviously silly feature file:

```
feature aalt {
    sub uni0061' uni0062 from [glyph01 glyph02 glyph03];
} aalt;
```

This works sucessfully (but I think it shouldn't):

```
from fontTools.feaLib.parser import Parser
file = open("test.fea","r")
parsetree = Parser(file, ()).parse()
print(parsetree)
```

And then trying to build that into a font gives a really weird error.

```
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/fontTools/feaLib/builder.py", line 1189, in setInputCoverage_
    coverage = otl.buildCoverage(g, self.glyphMap)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/fontTools/otlLib/builder.py", line 11, in buildCoverage
    self.glyphs = sorted(glyphs, key=glyphMap.__getitem__)
KeyError: 'u'
```

Clearly nobody should ever try to do this, so it might be a "you get what you deserve" thing. But I think your parser is more generic than it can actually handle. :-)

items.title: [feaLib] assertion error mixing pos and sub contextual chaining rules
items.body:
Because OpenType is... well, it is what it is - you can create a contextual chaining lookup either with a "pos" statement or a "sub" statement. In particular, you can create a contextual chaining lookup with a "position" statement even if the lookup you chain to is a substitution rule, and vice versa. The following feature code:

```
lookup dummy1 { pos uni0061 50; } dummy1;

feature kern {
    sub uni0061' lookup dummy1 uni0062;
} kern;
```

may not be entirely _sensible_, but it should cause a warning, not a crash:

items.title: Question: Is there a way to give a glyph multiple unicodes with TTFont?
items.body:
I'm hoping to produce a "trial font" that:
1. Is subset down to a basic set of characters (english alphabet, numbers, and a few symbols)
2. Maps many other unicodes to a `.notdef` glyph
3. Updates font names to append the suffix "Trial"

Part 1 can easily be done with pyftsubset, with the unicode values I wish to keep, with something like:

```bash
pyftsubset <fontPath> --unicodes="U+0020-007F --notdef-outline --name-IDs='*'
```

Part 3 can easily be done with TTFont, via the `.setName()` method for the `name` table.

However, I'm having trouble with Part 2. My guess, one could probably use TTfont and the `cmap` table, and assign multiple unicode codepoints to the `.notdef` glyph. 

I can do so directly in a TTX file, adding extra lines to the end of the format 4 tables in a cmap like:

```xml
<map code="0x2197" name=".notdef"/><!-- NORTH EAST ARROW -->
<map code="0x2198" name=".notdef"/><!-- SOUTH EAST ARROW -->
```

However, it would be much more ideal to do this kind of manipulation from a single Python script.

I see that I can open a font as a TTfont object, get a dictionary of the cmap table, and append new key-value pairs into that table. However, I am unsure of how (or whether) I can then save that edited cmap dict back into the TTfont.

```Python
ttfont = TTFont(fontPath)
currentCmap = ttfont['cmap'].buildReversed()
currentCmap['.notdef'] = {8596, 8597}
```

I have tried using the `compile()` and `decompile()` methods to save the edited cmap table back into the font, but these don’t seem to work (I admit, I don’t understand quite what these do, and whether they are useful to external scripts, or more for use within TTFont).

Is there a way to edit / append new values to a cmap table with TTFont? 

Is this a sensible approach, or am I missing a better way that this might be done?

Thanks so much for any advice or insight!

P.S. I'm not entirely sure, but it seems like issue https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/issues/1813 may be a question another user trying to do something similar, replacing a range of glyphs with the `space` glyph. If so, I assume the answer might be similar to both.

items.title: feaLib should build simple contextual lookups when no backtrack/lookahead
items.body:
The Adobe FEA spec does not distinguish between contextual positioning/substitution lookups (GPOS 7, GSUB 5), on the one hand, and _chaining_ contextual pos/subst lookups (GPOS 8, GSUB 6), on the other. The two types of lookups are essentially the same except that the latter also can define optional backtrack/lookahead sequences.

FeaLib builder currently always encodes contextual pos/subst rules with Format 3 (Coverage-based) ChainContex{Pos,Subst} lookup subtables.

https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/42dcfddfb9687de106e5deb59cea015280dd507f/Lib/fontTools/feaLib/builder.py#L1246

https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/42dcfddfb9687de106e5deb59cea015280dd507f/Lib/fontTools/feaLib/builder.py#L1293

Ideally it could use the more efficient types of non-chaining contextual lookups when a contextual rule contains no backtrack nor lookahend sequences.

http://adobe-type-tools.github.io/afdko/OpenTypeFeatureFileSpecification.html#5e-gsub-lookuptype-5-contextual-substitution
http://adobe-type-tools.github.io/afdko/OpenTypeFeatureFileSpecification.html#6g-gpos-lookuptype-7-contextual-positioning

I haven't had the chance to check, does makeotf do anything like that?

items.title: Importing a TTFont from XML fails when LC_TIME is set
items.body:
Importing a font from XML while LC_TIME locale is set to non-English, causes an error.

### How to reproduce?

This might be easy when a non-English locale is available in the system. I came across this, while using a package on top. The corresponding issue in their package is amueller/word_cloud#530. There is a script to reproduce, which only throws an error, when a non-English locale like 'de_DE' is set with e. g. `locale.setlocale(locale.LC_TIME, 'de_DE.UTF-8')` or just by opening Spyder-IDE.

**A simplified test is:**
```python
import locale
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_TIME, 'de_DE.UTF-8') # works if de_DE is available

from fontTools.misc.timeTools import timestampFromString,timestampToString,timestampNow
ts_now = timestampNow()
str_now = timestampToString(ts_now)
timestampFromString(str_now) # ValueError
```

Let's go into the cause of the error.

### Basics

The locale for LC_TIME can be checked with
```python
import locale
print(locale.getlocale(locale.LC_TIME))
```
This outputs `('de_DE', 'UTF-8')` in my case.

With this locale the following fails:
```python
import time
time.strptime('Mon', '%a')
# ValueError: unconverted data remains: n
```
`'Mo'` is the localized abbreviation in de_DE for Monday.

### TTFont

The method [`importXML`](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/master/Lib/fontTools/ttLib/ttFont.py#L318) in `TTFont` receives the font object as XML. This can contain created and modified dates. The XML is parsed by the `XMLReader`, which somehow uses the [`fromXML`](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/master/Lib/fontTools/ttLib/tables/_h_e_a_d.py#L107) method in `table__h_e_a_d`. There the created and modified dates are parsed using [`timestampFromString`](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/master/Lib/fontTools/misc/timeTools.py#L46) from timeTools. This helper function uses `time.strptime(value)`.

In my test case `value` is initialized from the 'created' attribute of a font as `'Mon Jan 8 12:28:04 2007'`, which throws the following error:
```
ValueError: time data 'Mon Jan  8 12:28:04 2007' does not match format '%a %b %d %H:%M:%S %Y'
```


### How to resolve?

I think the parsing should be done without locale, since the XML attribute is likely to be non-local. In the opposite function [`timestampToString`](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/master/Lib/fontTools/misc/timeTools.py#L43) `asctime` is used, which uses a fixed list of abbreviated week days and months. So that is not localized. Hence [`timestampFromString`](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/master/Lib/fontTools/misc/timeTools.py#L46) shouldn't be localized as well.

A simple solution could be
```python
def timestampFromString(value):
	import locale
	l = locale.getlocale(locale.LC_TIME)
	locale.setlocale(locale.LC_TIME, 'C')
	try:
		t = time.strptime(value)
	finally:
		locale.setlocale(locale.LC_TIME, l)
	return calendar.timegm(t) - epoch_diff
```

However, changing the locale is not recommended. It's better to use a function that can parse a date with specified locale without changing it. You could use [dateparser](https://dateparser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) for example, but I don't know about your dependencies and how you handle it.

items.title: [fealib] lookup flag ignored if it's declared before a script statement
[BUG] Alignment issue with CBLC/EBLC index format 3
items.body:
According to the spec CBLC/EBLC IndexSubtables using index format 3 need to be 32-bit aligned [1]. However, due to a bug in calculating if padding is required near line 482 of `E_B_L_C_.py` the resulting compiled table will always be 16-bit aligned. See the code for an explanation.

```python
dataList = [EblcIndexSubTable.compile(self, ttFont)]
# At this point len(dataList) == 1 this will be a problem when doing padding calculation.
# The first entry in dataList is already 32-bit aligned as it is:
# uint16 firstGlyphId
# uint16 lastGlyphId
# uint32 imageDataOffset

dataList += [struct.pack(dataFormat, offsetValue) for offsetValue in offsetArray]
# Now len(dataList) == 1 + # of offsets

# Only # of offsets should be considered for padding not the first entry in dataList
# len(dataList) should be len(offsetArray) or len(dataList) - 1
if offsetDataSize * len(dataList) % 4 != 0:
    dataList.append(struct.pack(dataFormat, 0))
```

[1] [Spec for IndexSubtables](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/typography/opentype/spec/eblc#indexsubtables)

https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/a37dab38243d8c1e88ab83376a80942012bbab48/Lib/fontTools/varLib/__init__.py#L852

items.title: Enable LGTM.com analysis on PRs
items.body:
Hi fonttools folks,

LGTM (AKA Semmle) is a free-for-open-source code analysis service, recently acquired by GitHub. It has [already been running an analysis on the fonttools codebase](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/fonttools/fonttools/history/) (among many other open source projects), and has identified lots of alerts of varying severity. In [adobe-type-tools](https://github.com/adobe-type-tools)-land, we've been running LGTM on [AFDKO](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/adobe-type-tools/afdko/?mode=tree) and [psautohint](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/adobe-type-tools/psautohint/?mode=tree) Pull Requests  for a few months now, and have been very pleased with the results. It has identified many potential issues that would not likely have been picked up by our test suite.

I propose enabling LGTM's analyze-on-PR for fonttools/fonttools repo as well. It's a fairly unobtrusive check, not too chatty, and does not block merging (it's informational-only). And addressing the existing [backlog of alerts](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/fonttools/fonttools/?mode=list) might be a good way for folks to contribute to the project and get familiar with the codebase.

See https://lgtm.com/ for more info.

items.title: [ufoLib/glifLib] .glif parser does not accept XML comments
items.body:
I just noticed that if a `.glif` file contains an XML comment, the data is rejected by `ufoLib.glifLib`. The following snippet causes an error:

```python
from fontTools.ufoLib.glifLib import readGlyphFromString

s = """<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<glyph name="A" format="2">
  <advance width="1290"/>
  <unicode hex="0041"/>
  <!-- a comment -->
</glyph>
"""

class Glyph:
    pass

g = Glyph()
readGlyphFromString(s, g)
```
Exception:
`fontTools.ufoLib.errors.GlifLibError: Unknown element in GLIF: <!-- a comment -->`

I bet this is unintentional.

(Note that I don't really mind this behavior, I just wanted it to be recorded.)

items.title: fontTools fails on python3.6 due to lack of ast.literal_eval function
items.body: In `texttools.py`, there is a reference to ast.literal_eval, which doesn't exist in python3.6. In the readme for the project, it mentions support for python3.6 or later. My guess is that ast.literal_eval is required and that the readme should be updated to python3.7 or later.

items.title: [subset] FeatureVariations subsetted incorrectly
items.body:
Take this font by @arrowtype which contains loads of GSUB rvrn FeatureVariations substitutions:
https://github.com/arrowtype/recursive/releases/download/1.027/recursive-MONO_CASL_wght_slnt_ital--full_gsub--2019_11_30-20_07.ttf

If you run `fonttools subset --unicodes='*'` on it, the "rvrn" feature and all its lookups are dropped, even though "rvrn" is in the subsetter's default list of layout features to keep. Also, if one explicitly adds "rvrn" to the `--layout-features+=rvrn` option, still it is being subsetted away.

I think the problem is that the `prune_pre_subset` stage is modifying the GSUB.table.FeatureList.FeatureRecord array (dropping feature records for tags not included in the options.layout_features). But then later, since the FeatureVariations references the feature records by their indexes and these may have changed inthe pre-subset pruning, the FeatureVariations record may be incorrectly dropped.

I have this patch that fixes the problem, but before I send a PR I want to make a good test case that reproduces the issue. I'll work on that later.

```diff
diff --git a/Lib/fontTools/subset/__init__.py b/Lib/fontTools/subset/__init__.py
index 581c3948..fea85f0e 100644
--- a/Lib/fontTools/subset/__init__.py
+++ b/Lib/fontTools/subset/__init__.py
@@ -1307,6 +1307,9 @@ def subset_features(self, feature_indices):
        self.ensureDecompiled()
        self.SubstitutionRecord = [r for r in self.SubstitutionRecord
                                     if r.FeatureIndex in feature_indices]
+       feature_index_map = dict(zip(feature_indices, range(len(feature_indices))))
+       for r in self.SubstitutionRecord:
+               r.FeatureIndex = feature_index_map[r.FeatureIndex]
        self.SubstitutionCount = len(self.SubstitutionRecord)
        return bool(self.SubstitutionCount)

```

Thanks @arrowtype for reporting this bug! :+1

items.title: Bad font data after instantiating variable font
items.body:
I'm coming across bad font data when using fontTools pens to interact with instantiated variable fonts. The problem can be reproduced in every contour in every Quadratic variable font I've tried.

When reading the point data with a pen, the point order is offset by one (which in this case I don't mind) and the last two `lineTo` points are joined together into a `qCurve` segment (which distorts the shape). The problem happens in both the `instancer` and `mutator` variations of the `instantiateVariableFont` function.

However, the font data in the TTF looks fine to me when I save it to a file and open it in an editor or read through a TTX dump.

This demo just happens to use Monserrat (to make sure that the problem wasn't in my own font) and I set the location to the default weight to make the output comparison more clear, but the problem happens at any location (and with any Quadratic TTF)

Can anyone think of what I might be doing wrong, or where the problem might be coming from?


```python
from fontTools.varLib import mutator, instancer
from fontTools.ttLib import TTFont
from fontTools.pens.recordingPen import RecordingPen


def printReport(f):
    g = f.getGlyphSet()["I"]
    pen = RecordingPen()
    g.draw(pen)
    for i in pen.value:
        print(i)  

fontPath = "Montserrat-VF.ttf"
location = {"wght":100}

print("Default:")
f = TTFont(fontPath)
printReport(f)

print("\nmutator.instantiateVariableFont")
instM = mutator.instantiateVariableFont(f, location)
#instM.save("mutator.ttf")
printReport(instM)

print("\ninstancer.instantiateVariableFont")
instI = instancer.instantiateVariableFont(f, location)
#instI.save("instancer.ttf")
printReport(instI)
```

Output:

```
Default:
('moveTo', ((133, 700),))
('lineTo', ((153, 700),))
('lineTo', ((153, 0),))
('lineTo', ((133, 0),))
('lineTo', ((133, 700),))
('closePath', ())

mutator.instantiateVariableFont
('moveTo', ((153, 700),))
('lineTo', ((153, 0),))
('lineTo', ((133, 0),))
('qCurveTo', ((133, 700), (153, 700)))
('closePath', ())

instancer.instantiateVariableFont
('moveTo', ((153, 700),))
('lineTo', ((153, 0),))
('lineTo', ((133, 0),))
('qCurveTo', ((133, 700), (153, 700)))
('closePath', ())
```

from fontTools.feaLib.parser import Parser

items.title: [ufoLib] Forced up-conversion to UFO3
items.body:
When opening a UFO2 generated by `vfb2ufo`, it is forced to UFO3. There I run into an error with upgrading the kerning group names. The code responsible for this is basically the UFO sample implementation, so I opened an issue there: https://github.com/unified-font-object/ufo-spec/issues/98

Any way from the ufoLib side to avoid the ambiguity around how group names are extracted from the kerning items?

Or, because my UFO process is one-way only, I would be happy to open the UFO keeping version 2, then processing the groups and throwing out the ambiguous names before converting up to 3. But it seems a forced upgrade to version 3 now.

items.title: why is Symbol cmap (3, 0) classified as isUnicode()?
items.body:
the cmap OT spec lists "Symbol" (platform=3, platEncId=0) among the "other non-Unicode encodings":

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/typography/opentype/spec/cmap#windows-platform-platform-id--3 

but isUnicode() method of cmap subtable includes Symbol among the Unicode subtable:

https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/4e9fa7a44c13f4adb88c67f1c1751d2cbc788949/Lib/fontTools/ttLib/tables/_c_m_a_p.py#L210-L215

I wonder why that's the case?

items.title: [feaLib] Raise specific exception when a glyph referenced in a feature file does not exist in the font
items.body: So we can print a user-friendly error message for cases like https://github.com/googlefonts/fontmake/issues/584#issuecomment-531458280.

items.title: ascender and ascent
items.body:
The [opentype spec ](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/typography/opentype/spec/hhea) calls the first two substantive entries in the `hhea` table "`ascender`" and "`descender`". fonttools calls them "`ascent`" and "`descent`".

This was surprising! Maybe it's too late to change then but can we at least have an alias?

items.title: [subset]  the subsetter should optimize lookup types for SinglePos as well
items.body:
SingleSubst optimizes lookup format in custom "preWrite":
https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/master/Lib/fontTools/ttLib/tables/otTables.py#L725

I think we should do the same optimization for SinglePos as well

I was trying to build a variable TTF with fontmake, and I ran into an error which I have tried a bunch of workarounds for before finding a solution (https://github.com/arrowtype/recursive/issues/131). In the end, I found the solution: making sure all glyphs between all fonts had the exact same anchors. I think I may have run into this in the past so I already had a script to check for anchor consistency, but I had just forgotten to run it again before building. ([Here's a permalink to this RoboFont script](https://github.com/arrowtype/recursive/blob/bc98142f8944c9fd28e6afa20501b382cba04fdb/src/00-recursive-scripts-for-robofont/checking-similarity-between-fonts/check-anchor-similarity-selected-fonts.py)). items.title: Asking for help – Corrupted UFO won't open: GlifLibError("line can not have an offcurve.")
items.body:
I'm trying to open a UFO, but RoboFont crashes each time. This may be caused by merging different versions of a glyph with Git. The error I'm getting in the RF log is: ``` GlifLibError: line can not have an offcurve. ``` So, it seems that I have a corrupted outline somewhere, but it's unclear where, exactly. I can revert a glyph or glyphs to an earlier version if it is causing the problem, but I'd rather not revert everything, as there are quite a few changed glyphs in the branch I'm merging, and that would potentially lose a fair bit of work just to avoid an issue that might be really small. Is there a way that I could find which glyph is failing to open? For instance, is there a good way that a fontTools script could go through glyphs, printing each name before attempting to open it, or even printing paths as it tries to read them? That way, I might be able to see where the issue is. I know that this isn't really an issue with FontTools, but I'm just fishing for help as I'm feeling somewhat stuck. I'll report back if I figure this out on my own, but if anyone has any insights, that would be amazing!

items.title: fontTools.t1Lib.T1Error: can't find end of eexec part
Invalid RegionAxisCount in varLib for single master VF's
items.body:
Compiling a single master designspace (where the master is located at the default of the axis) generates a VF which is not sanitizing. Duplicating this master solves the problem, but is not practical. 
See also  https://github.com/googlefonts/fontmake/issues/565

items.title: [designspaceLib] Default font not set as described in spec
items.body:
The designspace spec (see fonttools/Doc/source/designspaceLib/) says "The source with the copyInfo flag indicates this is the default font." This matches what I have always thought, that you add the child element <info copy="1"> to a source file in order to make it be the default source font for a variation font. 

However, poking around in varLib.__init__.py::load_designspace() and experimenting with design space files shows that the default font is now set by setting the  'default' attribute of the axis elements. The source font element whose location matches the axis default attributes is set to be the default font. I am fine with this, but we then need to update the design space spec. Or am I missing something?

items.title: How can I modify a source attribute in a designspace file? I'm so close!
items.body:
_I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask a usage question, but the forum mentioned in the contribution guidelines is either down or doesn't exist (https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/issues/1629). I'm also not able to find anything through Google. However, please let me know if I should move elsewhere with this question._

---

How I might set source `filename` attributes in a designspace file?

**Context:** 

I have [a script that takes in a designspace file and preps sources for interpolation into a prototype variable font](https://github.com/thundernixon/varfont-prep/blob/read-designspace/varfont-prep.py) by simply copying the UFOs into a timestamped folder and chucking out all incompatible glyphs. This is a "stupid" way to prep fonts for building, but it's pretty useful to allow me to check a variable font in browsers, etc, well before it the project has been totally finished.

However, this script currently only works if the designspace only points to UFOs in its own, same directory. I'd like to be able to go through and update the `filename` attribute of sources to correctly point to the new timestamped folder, if they have been copied in from other directories. But, once I have set source attributes to edited values, I'm having trouble making the attributes "stick" while I write a new designspace file.

Here's my current copy and edit function ([from here](https://github.com/thundernixon/varfont-prep/blob/read-designspace/varfont-prep.py#L119)):

```python
def copyDesignSpace(designspacePath):

    # duplicate designspace into new folder
    inputDStail = os.path.split(designspacePath)[1]
    outputDSpath = newFolderPath + "/" + inputDStail

    shutil.copyfile(designspacePath, outputDSpath)

    # update source & instance paths in designspace as needed
    outputDS = DesignSpaceDocument.fromfile(outputDSpath)

    for source in outputDS.sources:
        print(source.filename)  # prints the original value

        fontFilename = os.path.split(source.path)[1]
        setattr(source, 'filename', fontFilename)

        print(source.filename)  # this does change to the value I want

    # this doesn't overwrite the designspace file...
    outputDS.write(outputDSpath.replace(
        ".designspace", ".prepped.designspace"))


copyDesignSpace(designspacePath)
```

I think I'm close, but just missing something. If I find it, I'll update this thread. If someone else is able to point out what I'm missing, I would really appreciate the nudge in the right direction!

items.title: [varLib.featureVar] Need to be able to generate 'rclt' and/or 'rlig'
items.body:
'rvrn' has some serious limitations, as seen in #1371 and discussed on the OpenType mailing list.

@behdad wrote in that discussion:

> Can we agree to change description of either 'rclt' or 'rlig' to be *the* global feature that should be used for whatever font designer wants, GSUB and GPOS?

So, while the spec would need to be edited to reflect this suggestion, the documented behavior of 'rclt' and 'rlig' are suitable for our needs, and `fontTools.varLib.featureVars` should be extended to make this possible.

Ideally, this should also trickle up to designspaceLib, at least as an option.

items.title: [varLib] Merging vpal GPOS feature can't handle differing number of subtables
items.body:
The vpal GPOS feature can be constructed differently in different source fonts. A glyph may require both and xAdvance and xPlacement adjustment in one font, and only a xAdvance in another fonts. Also in one font, a long sequence of glyphs may use the same value record, but the same sequence of glyphs may use the same value record format, but have different adjustment values. These differences lead to the source fonts having a different number of subtables after optimization for size. The current code can't merge the features if the source fonts differ in number of subtables, or if the subtables  differ in coverage or number of value records. I attached a small test case. The GPOS data is edited in rather arbitrarily. If you have the afdko, you can build this with 'buildcff2vf -d test_vpal.designspace'.
[test_vpal.zip](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/files/3230051/test_vpal.zip)
